I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The Government of the Republic of Uzbekistan has requested Asian Development Bank 
(ADB) technical assistance (TA) to formulate a railway development project covering priority 
lines of the network (see map). The Fact-Finding Mission visited Uzbekistan in October 2002, 
and held discussions with representatives of the Government and Uzbekistan Railways (UTY). 
An understanding was reached with the Government and UTY on the TA objectives, scope, 
terms of reference, cost estimates and financing plan, and implementation arrangements. This 
paper is based on the understanding reached with the Government and UTY and the Mission's 
observations. The TA is included in ADB’s 2002 Country Assistance Plan.1 
 
II.  ISSUES 
2.  Uzbekistan has an area of nearly 450,000 square kilometers and a population of 22.5 
million. The country is a major agricultural producer and is rich in natural resources. Despite its 
potential, Uzbekistan's per capita gross domestic product of $451 in 2001 was among the 
lowest in the region. Landlocked, Uzbekistan is highly dependent on land transport to support its 
external trade and domestic economy. Much of the country's land transport infrastructure needs 
rehabilitation. Major inefficiencies are caused by rigid price controls and distorted incentive 
structures. 
 
3.  Uzbekistan’s geopolitical location makes the railway a key link in the strategic Eurasian 
Corridor linking Asia and Europe.2 The railway system, about 4,200 route-kilometers (km) of 
track,  including  700  route-km  of  double  lines  and  350  route-km  of  electrified  lines,  is 
Government owned and operated by UTY.3 As the dominant transportation mode, the railway 
carries over 75% of all freight volume in ton-km, with road transport accounting for the rest. 
Railway passenger traffic accounts for over 20% of passenger-km, and roads and civil aviation 
account for the remaining passenger services.  
 
4.  Since independence in 1991, inadequate capital investment, combined with the shortage 
of materials and spare parts from Russia, Ukraine, and the Eastern European countries, and 
scarcity  of  foreign  exchange,  have  exacerbated  the  problem  of  maintaining  the  railway 
infrastructure. A sizable portion of the track that carries the bulk of national and international 
traffic has outlived its economic life and is overdue for replacement. As the country progresses 
to a market-oriented economy, the demand for traffic is changing, with increasing emphasis on 
service quality and cost-effectiveness. Competition from other transport modes, particularly road 
transport,  is  increasing.  As  a  result,  the  railway  subsector  faces  serious  problems  in  the 
condition of physical infrastructure, its operations, and its ability to operate successfully in a free 
market environment. ADB has reviewed the needs of the railway subsector through 3 TA 
projects.4

5.  In response to the Government’s request for assistance to the railway subsector, ADB 
provided Loans 1631-UZB and 1773-UZB for two railway projects,5 which are rehabilitating 661 
km of railway track. Under Loan 1631-UZB, the procurement of most of the materials and 
equipment through international tenders is complete and rehabilitation of track is progressing 
with some delay. Under Loan 1773-UZB, procurement of materials and equipment through 
international  tenders  is  progressing  although  with  some  delay.  Rehabilitation  of  track  is 
expected to start in 2003 (after the supply of materials and equipment) and will take about 3 
years to complete. The progress of implementation of the two projects is being monitored by 
UTY’s Project Implementation Unit (PIU). Other than some delays in implementation, no major 
problems are envisaged in implementation of these projects. 
 
6.  ADB's ongoing railway projects include time-bound reform frameworks that were agreed 
to by ADB, the Government, and UTY. The Railway Reforms Commission, established in June 
1997, is coordinating reform implementation.  An asset-downsizing plan has been prepared, and 
eight  freight  stations  have  been  closed.  The  staff  reduction  plan  is  also  progressing 
satisfactorily, and the number of staff was reduced to 40,9876 by the end of 2001, much lower 
than the target of 43,998. The plan to separate educational facilities has been implemented, and 
30 secondary schools and 91 kindergartens have been handed over to local authorities. Under 
separation of nonrailway ancillary units and their privatization, 26 units have been separated 
from UTY. The Small Business Fund was set up to help separated staff establish small business 
ventures.  UTY also achieved a working ratio below 0.95 for 2001 and 0.88 as of July 2002.  
 
7.  Under TA 3529-UZB,7 crucial institutional support is being provided to prepare the 
necessary regulatory framework, help UTY become a commercial operation, improve UTY’s 
financial management and marketing capabilities, and prepare measures to mitigate the social 
impacts of staff reduction and other organizational reforms. The consultants submitted their 
interim report in August 2002, and the draft final report will be submitted in December 2002. 
 
8.  Since  1996,  ADB  has  been  leading  the  coordination  of  external  assistance  and 
development of reforms in the railway subsector. Besides ADB, Japan (through the Japan Bank 
for International Cooperation [JBIC]), the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development 
(EBRD), and the European Union (EU) are assisting the railway subsector. JBIC has financed 
the Railway Passenger Transportation Improvement Project, under which repair facilities for 
passenger coaches have been set up and new coaches supplied to UTY. Under a second JBIC 
project, repair facilities for electric locomotives are being set up.  Through the EU-funded 
Transport  Corridor  for  Europe-Caucasus-Asia  program,  a  study  of  railway  electrification, 
telecommunications, and management information systems has been undertaken. EBRD is 
financing  procurement  of  electric  locomotives  and  the  modernization  of  diesel  electric 
locomotives. ADB worked with EBRD on developing a comprehensive reform framework and 
capital investment strategy for UTY. Cooperation between EBRD and ADB will continue during 
project preparation.  
 
9.  Efficient operation of UTY is critical to economic growth in landlocked Uzbekistan and is 
important for regional cooperation. Consistent with ADB's sectoral strategy for Uzbekistan, ADB 
will support the Government's ongoing economic transition to a market-based economy  by 
helping the railway subsector develop an efficient policy and regulatory framework and by

III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Purpose and Output 
10.  The TA objective is to prepare a project that helps the Government improve sector 
efficiency to meet the transportation needs of the domestic economy and international traffic. 
The TA will continue ADB’s support for sound sector policy to facilitate market-based transport 
management and operations. A TA framework is in Appendix 1. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
11.  The TA scope includes the preparation of a feasibility study for a railway development 
project suitable for external financing. The feasibility study will be prepared in consultation with 
the Government, UTY, and other concerned agencies, and will consider all studies done by 
ADB, other multilateral agencies, and bilateral agencies. The study will cover all relevant areas, 
including technical, financial, and economic viability; environmental impacts; institutional and 
organizational aspects; and social and poverty impacts in accordance with ADB’s guidelines. 
The TA will support enterprise reforms and restructuring of UTY and assess the opportunities to 
promote good governance in operations, and procedures to enhance UTY’s efficiency and help 
UTY achieve financial self-sufficiency in a market environment. Outline terms of reference for 
the consultants are in Appendix 2. The TA will conduct a prescreening of the following options 
for inclusion in the subsequent project: 
 
(i)  rehabilitation of track from Samarkand to Karshi (139 km); 
 
(ii)  rehabilitation of track from Navoi to Uchkuduk (182 km, excluding 97 km already 
rehabilitated by UTY); 
 
(iii)  introduction of modern traffic and rolling stock control systems on UTY; and 
 
(iv)  improvements  to  the  UTY  lines  comprising  part  of  the  Khavast-Bekhabad-
Khanebadam-Fergana route to complement a proposed rehabilitation project with 
Tajikistan Railways, in accordance with ADB’s active involvement in encouraging 
regional cooperation among the Central Asian republics. 
 
12.  The results of the prescreening of the above options will be presented in the interim 
report.  Following  agreement  by  UTY,  the  Government,  and  ADB  on  the  results  of  the 
prescreening of the above options, a full feasibility study will be prepared for the preferred 
option.  As  requested  by  the  Government,  the  consultants  will  also  conduct  preliminary 
screening of any other railway investment options such as a railway line from Angren to Pap for 
separate future examination.  
 
13.  Since rehabilitation will be carried out on the existing railway track, no adverse land 
acquisition,  resettlement,  or  adverse  environmental  impacts  are  expected.  However,  in 
accordance with ADB’s guidelines, an initial environmental examination (IEE) will be carried out, 
as will a poverty and social analysis (PSA). The summary initial PSA is in Appendix 3.

4  
C.  Cost and Financing  
14.  The total TA cost is estimated to be $860,000 equivalent comprising a foreign exchange 
cost of $510,000 and a local currency cost of $350,000 equivalent. Accordingly, a TA grant of 
$600,000 will be proposed for ADB financing to cover the entire foreign exchange cost of 
$510,000 and $90,000 equivalent of the local currency cost. The TA will be financed by ADB on 
a grant basis from the Japan Special Fund, funded by the Government of Japan. The remaining 
local cost of $260,000 equivalent will  be provided by the Government, mainly in kind. The 
details of the cost estimates and financing plan are in Appendix 4. The Government was 
advised that approval of the TA and its implementation does not commit ADB to finance any 
ensuing project.8 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
15.  The  Executing  Agency  for  the  TA  will  be  UTY.  A  project  coordinating  committee 
comprising  representatives  of  the  concerned  railway  departments  and  headed  by  the 
chairperson of UTY or his/her representative will be set up to monitor the TA’s progress and 
resolve any issues. UTY will also appoint a project coordinator to coordinate and supervise the 
work of the consultants on a day-to-day basis and serve as a liaison between the consultants 
and other concerned agencies. 
 
16.  The TA will require about 35 person-months of consulting services, consisting of 15 
person-months of international consultants and 20 person-months of domestic consultants. 
International  consultants  will  have  expertise  in  the  following  fields:  transport  economics, 
financial analysis, railway engineering and operations, information technology, environmental 
analysis, poverty and social analysis, transport policy analysis, and institutional restructuring. 
Domestic  consultants  will  have  expertise  in  railway  engineering  and  operations,  financial 
analysis, information technology, and environmental and social analysis. A team of consultants 
from an international consulting firm, in association with domestic consultants, will be selected 
and engaged by ADB using the quality- and cost-based selection method in accordance with 
ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants. Office equipment will be procured in accordance 
with arrangements acceptable to ADB. 
 
17.  To  facilitate  the  work  of  the  consultants  and  ensure  that  UTY  benefits  from  their 
experience, the consultants will work closely with counterpart staff from UTY, who will be 
technical  experts  in  railway  engineering  and  operations,  transport  economics,  information 
technology, and financial analysis. Other technical staff will be made available by UTY to assist 
in fieldwork. The Government has agreed that the counterpart staff will be provided in a timely 
manner. 
 
18.  TA implementation is expected to start in May 2003 and to be completed in about 7 
months, by November 2003. An inception report will be submitted by the consultants within one 
month of starting work. The consultant will submit brief progress reports monthly and interact 
regularly with staff of UTY and any other interested government organizations concerning TA 
techniques, analysis, and findings. The consultants will submit an IEE report together with a 
summary IEE report. After ADB's review, the consultants will be advised if the IEE and summary 
IEE are to be finalized on the basis of comments by ADB and the Government. The consultants 
will submit an initial social assessment report to ADB and the Government for review. An interim

report  containing  the  results  of  the  prescreening  will  be  submitted  within  3  months  of 
commencement of the TA. A draft final report, comprising a full feasibility study and including a 
detailed PSA, will be submitted within 5 months. The draft final report will be reviewed by UTY, 
the Government, and ADB, and comments will be finalized at a final tripartite meeting (among 
UTY, the Government, consultants, and ADB) to be held in Tashkent. The consultants will 
submit a final report within 3 weeks of receipt of comments from UTY and ADB. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION  
19.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $600,000 on a grant basis to 
the Government of Uzbekistan for preparing the  Third Railway Development Project, and 
hereby reports this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  Scope 
 
1.  The scope of the technical assistance (TA) includes conducting a prescreening exercise 
of the following options: (i) rehabilitation of track from Samarkand to Karshi (139 km); (ii) 
rehabilitation of track from Navoi to Uchkuduk (182 km, excluding 97 km already rehabilitated by 
UTY); (iii) introduction of modern traffic and rolling stock control systems on UTY; and (iv) 
improvements  to  the  UTY  lines  comprising  part  of  the  Khavast-Bekhabad-Khanebadam-
Fergana route to complement a proposed rehabilitation project with Tajikistan Railways, in 
accordance with ADB’s active involvement in encouraging regional cooperation among the 
Central Asian republics. As requested by the Government, the consultants will also conduct 
preliminary screening of any other railway investment options such as a railway line from 
Angren to Pap for separate future examination.  
 
B.  Terms of Reference 
 
2.  The tasks to be undertaken by the consultant will include the following: 
 
1.  Technical 
 
3.  The consultant will have the following tasks:  
 
(i)  The consultant will (a) review the operational performance of UTY and the extent 
to which the performance indicators agreed on under Loans 1631-UZB and 
1733-UZB have been achieved; (b) identify areas for further improvement and 
the likely economic and financial benefits resulting from such improvements, 
which will form the basis for the policy reform and investment interventions under 
the  Project;  and  (c)  recommend  time-bound  targets  for  a  set  of  operations 
parameters for monitoring and evaluation. 
(ii)  Based on the review of operational performance, (a) review the condition of 
operations facilities such as track signaling, telecommunications, rolling stock, 
locomotives, maintenance facilities, rolling stock control systems, traffic control 
systems, etc.; and (b) identify constraints to efficient operations.  
(iii)  Review UTY’s program to address other infrastructure constraints and make 
recommendations, giving budget estimates.  
(iv)  Review and update UTY’s capital asset investment program. 
(v)  Assess the requirements for materials, equipment, and services to implement the 
investment  component,  giving  due  consideration  to  the  equipment  procured 
under Loans 1631-UZB and 1773-UZB.  
(vi)  Prepare cost estimates of the investment component as per ADB’s requirements 
on the basis of current international and domestic prices of materials, equipment, 
and services, including environmental and social costs, if any, and provide for 
appropriate physical and price contingencies. Separately estimate the foreign 
exchange cost (direct and indirect), local currency cost, and local taxes and 
duties.  
(vii)  Review  in  consultation  with  the  Government  and  UTY  the  possibility  of 
cofinancing, and propose a financing plan for the Project. 
(viii)  Prepare  a  list  of  contract  packages  for  ADB  financing,  giving  a  detailed 
justification, estimated contract value, and mode of procurement. Review and 
propose measures to encourage participation in bidding by international bidders 
from among ADB’s member countries. Ensure Government and UTY agreement 
on contract packages to be financed by ADB.

8  Appendix 2 
 
(ix)  Review the organizational arrangements to undertake the policy and investment 
components.  Assess  the  need  for  consultant  input  for  implementation 
supervision. Prepare a project implementation schedule taking into consideration 
all major activities, logistics of procurement, and seasonal aspects. 
(x)  Prepare a project framework that logically outlines the goals, objectives, outputs, 
and activities/inputs under the Project; integrates the economic and social effects 
of the Project; ensures transparency and accountability; promotes the efficient 
use of resources; and provides the basis for monitoring and evaluation. 
(xi)  Review and describe the work done in the railway subsector by other multilateral 
and bilateral agencies, including the European Bank for Reconstruction and 
Development, World Bank, European Union, Japan, and others, giving in brief 
the nature of intervention, assistance provided, and the current status. The future 
program of work should be indicated to the extent known. 
(xii)  Review and update the asset downsizing program and arrangements for disposal 
of assets, and make recommendations. 
(xiii)  Review the status of private sector participation in the railway subsector, and 
recommend areas and measures to enhance such involvement. 
 
2.  Economic  
 
4.  The consultants will have the following tasks: 
  
(i)  Provide  a  clear  statement  of  the  project  rationale  and  a  rationale  for  ADB 
involvement. Assess relevance of the Project to the overall development strategy 
and the sectoral strategy, priority of the Project for public investment; and the 
policy environment for the Project covering taxes, exchange rates, interest rates, 
etc. 
(ii)  Review  the  demand  for  railway  transport  and  prepare  a  traffic  forecast  by 
commodity. Identify other means of meeting transport demand and assess their 
impact on the traffic forecast. Estimate economic costs of rail and road transport 
to  determine  the  allocation  of  freight  (by  commodity)  and  passenger  traffic 
between these modes. These estimates should take into account work done 
under other ADB projects in the region. Shipment times for each of the modes 
should  be  estimated  and  used  to  estimate  diverted  traffic.  The  impact  on 
transport  costs  of  anticipated  road  projects  should  also  be  included.  After 
considering the above and taking into account experience under other ADB- 
financed railway projects, prepare a realistic traffic forecast for the rehabilitation 
period and subsequent 20 years. The traffic forecast should be broken down by 
commodity, loaded and unloaded, in tons and ton-km moved, and number of 
passengers and passenger-km, split for through (or transit) traffic and traffic with 
origin or destination in Uzbekistan. The traffic forecast should include estimated 
frequency of freight and passenger trains on the sections of the track to be 
rehabilitated. 
(iii)  Conduct a prescreening analysis of the options listed in para. 1, based on 
expected traffic, costs, and other data, and recommend the option likely to be 
most feasible. The results will be presented in the interim report. 
(iv)  For  the  option  selected  by  ADB,  the  Government,  and  UTY  after  the 
prescreening exercise, identify all project costs and benefits, comparing with- and 
without-project situations. Undertake  an economic evaluation of the Project by 
following  ADB’s  Guidelines  on  Economic  Analysis  of  Projects.  Estimate  the 
economic internal rate of return  on the basis of nonincremental and incremental 
economic benefits (including environmental and socioeconomic benefits) and 
economic costs (including economic capital, operating, and maintenance costs), 
in constant prices using with- and without-project situations. The analysis should

Appendix 2  9
be carried out by using a consistent set of national economic parameters and 
standard conversion factors/shadow exchange rate factors, identifying the traded 
and nontraded components of both economic costs and benefits, and applying 
the standard conversion factor to nontraded items (or a shadow exchange rate 
factor to the traded items). The economic analysis should examine, but not 
necessarily be limited to, the following categories of benefits: savings from track 
maintenance and repair that would be incurred without the Project, inventory cost 
savings, operating cost savings, avoided rolling stock investment, and avoided 
diverted  traffic.  Benefits  arising  from  through  (or  transit)  traffic  should  be 
calculated separately. Separate estimates should be made of economic benefits 
from improvement of operating efficiency (due to policy reforms, restructuring, 
and improved governance). The estimated measures of productivity, for example, 
improvement of wagon cycle productivity, underlying the benefits from operating 
efficiency improvements, and others should be provided. 
(v)  Undertake sensitivity and risk analysis to assess the effects on the Project due to 
adverse  changes  in  key  variables  such  as  project  cost,  decrease  in  traffic, 
implementation delay and exchange rate fluctuations, taken separately and in 
combination, in accordance with ADB's Handbook for Integrating Risk Analysis in 
Economic Analysis of Projects. The results of the sensitivity analysis should be 
summarized in a sensitivity indicator and in a switching value. In case the Project 
is sensitive to the value of a key variable that is uncertain, mitigating measures 
should be recommended. 
(vi)  Assess the development impact of the Project focusing on generated economic 
activities. The estimate of development should be accompanied by appropriate 
monitoring and evaluation indicators. 
(vii)  Estimate the expected distribution of net project benefits among users of freight 
and  passenger  transport,  the  Government  and  UTY,  labor,  the  economy  in 
general, lenders, and any other beneficiaries. Estimate the number of poor and 
extremely  poor  people  who  will  benefit  from  the  Project  by  calculating  the 
project's poverty impact ratio based on results of the distribution analysis and in 
accordance with ADB's Handbook for Integrating Poverty Impact Assessment in 
the Economic Analysis of Projects. 
 
3.  Financial  
 
5.  The consultant will have the following tasks:  
 
(i)  Undertake  a  financial  evaluation  of  the  Project  in  accordance  with  ADB’s 
Guidelines  for  the  Financial  Governance  and  Management  of  Investment 
Projects  Financed  by  the  Asian  Development  Bank.  Estimate  the  financial 
internal rate of return  based on the difference between the without- and with-
project values of assets at the end of the economic life of the Project. Compare 
the FIRR with the EIRR and explain the reasons for differences, if any. 
(ii)  Identify risk factors and test the sensitivity of the Project to them, and propose 
mitigating measures. Undertake sensitivity analysis by varying tariff rates, project 
cost, implementation delay, traffic volume, and combinations of these factors. 
Switching values for these factors, excluding implementation delay, should also 
be calculated. Review the sensitivity of the financial viability of the Project to 
future exchange rate movements. 
(iii)  Review  and  analyze  the  financial  performance  of  UTY  by  reference  to  the 
projections made under Loans 1631-UZB and 1773-UZB. The analysis should 
include comments on operating performance, liquidity and returns on investment, 
achievements, and shortfalls, if any. Assess the impact of the capital assets 
investment program on the financial projections.

(iv)  Compare the tariff rates with those offered by alternative road transport. Assess 
the adequacy of the tariff rates to ensure sustained financial viability of UTY 
(covering operation and maintenance costs, depreciation, debt service in excess 
of depreciation, taxes, and a reasonable profit), and recommend appropriate tariff 
levels for freight and passenger traffic. 
(v)  Prepare  pro  forma  financial  statements  at  current  prices  for  UTY,  including 
balance sheet, income statement, and cash flow statement covering a period of 
15 years. Assumptions made in the financial statements should be explained in 
detail. 
(vi)  Present  two  seminars  for  staff  nominated  by  the  Government  and  UTY  to 
improve  their  understanding  and  interpretation  of  international  accounting 
standards to prepare project accounts and financial statements as applicable to a 
railway commercial enterprise. 
 
4.  Institutional  
 
6.  The consultant will have the following tasks:  
 
(i)  Review the status of implementation of reforms and restructuring under Loans 
1631-UZB and 1773-UZB, and the recommendations made under TAs 3068-UZB 
and 3529-UZB; identify progress in compliance and delays, if any, and give 
reasons for delays. Assess the impact of reforms and restructuring on UTY in 
terms of financial and economic impacts and the quality of governance in the 
railway subsector. 
(ii)  Review the progress made in separating ancillary activities and reducing staff in 
core operations. Assess future needs and make recommendations. 
(iii)  Identify institutional and reform measures that may form a basis for further policy 
dialogue with the Government and UTY to promote good governance in railway 
operations and procedures and improve the efficiency and financial viability of 
UTY. The policy dialogue may include, but not be limited to, economic reforms 
for project financing, autonomy of management, commercialization, accounting 
systems, financial planning and analysis, financial reporting and control, tariffs, 
resource  mobilization,  management  information  systems,  technological 
modernization, social dimensions, and environmental management. Propose in 
consultation with UTY a time-bound action plan for implementation of the policy 
reforms. 
 
5.  Environmental  
 
7.  The consultant will have the following tasks:  
 
(i)  Prepare an initial environmental examination (IEE) report and a summary IEE 
report in accordance with the Environmental Assessment Requirements of the 
Asian Development Bank and government requirements. The IEE should include 
the following major elements: (a) description of the Project, (b) description of the

6.  Poverty and Social Analysis  
 
8.  The consultant will have the following tasks:  
 
(i)  Conduct screening and an initial social assessment (ISA) in accordance with 
ADB's  policy  guidelines1  including  resettlement  effects,  indigenous 
peoples/ethnic  minorities,  gender,  and  social  protection.  The  ISA  will  be 
discussed with ADB and will become the basis for conducting a full poverty and 
social analysis. 
(ii)  Conduct a poverty and social analysis in accordance with ADB’s Handbook on 
Poverty and Social Analysis. Assess how the proposed rehabilitation may help 
improve people's livelihoods. The analysis will estimate (a) the number of project 
beneficiaries by area, occupation, and income level (low, medium, and high); and 
(b) the number of adversely affected people by type of impact. Specify how the 
Project will improve benefits (market access, employment opportunities, lower 
transport costs, reduced travel time, etc.) for local people by income group. 
Recommend  measures  to  enhance  benefits  and  minimize  adverse  impacts, 
particularly  for  the  poor.  The  costs  of  such  measures  and  the  means  for 
implementation should be clearly described in the project reports. 
(iii)  Build on the work done under Loans 1631-UZB and 1733-UZB, and TAs 3068-
UZB and 3529-UZB to provide program support to mitigate the social costs of 
transition. Recommend appropriate measures to address key social issues, e.g., 
staff redeployment, gender, indigenous peoples/ethnic minorities, and any other 
vulnerable  groups,  and  promote  development  opportunities  during  the 
rehabilitation work. 
(iv)  Help UTY establish consultation and participatory processes that will continue 
throughout  project  design  and  implementation.  The  needs  and  demands  of 
stakeholders  should  be  identified  and  considered  for  incorporation  into  the 
Project or as parallel initiatives. Prepare a public participation and consultation 
report, which should be updated by UTY throughout project implementation. 
(v)  Review the Government's policy, strategy, and programs for poverty reduction 
and regional economic development as they pertain to the project areas. Analyze 
how  the  proposed  railway  project  will  complement  the  Government's 
development programs. 
(vi)  Prepare a resettlement plan, in compliance with ADB's  Policy on Involuntary 
Resettlement, if any new construction is needed or if resettlement effects for 
assets, incomes, or living standards are identified along an existing alignment 
that is to be rehabilitated. 
(vii)  Help prepare the performance monitoring and evaluation systems, including a 
reporting format and instructions for the monitoring indicators.
